articles.title: Hurricane Melissa deals another heavy blow to Jamaica's farmers and fi...
articles.author: Gabriela Aoun Angueira
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is blamed for at least 28 deaths in Jamaica. The storm destroyed the homes and infrastructure of Jamaican fishers and farmers who feed their families and nearby communities. The World Food Program is concerned about the impact on Cuba and Haiti's small-scale farmers.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa deals another heavy blow to Jamaica's farmers and fishers
articles.author: GABRIELA AOUN ANGUEIRA
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has devastated Jamaica, causing severe damage to fishing and farming communities. Prince Davis, a fisherman, discovered his boat and home were destroyed while he was in Nicaragua and he is in Nicaragua now.       .   ...

articles.title: Los Reynaldos community, in Santiago de Cuba, remains cut off after the bridge collapse
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The Los Reynaldos community in Songo la Maya, Santiago de Cuba, remains isolated following the collapse of a bridge. The village of Brazo Escondido, located in the hills of Tercer Frente, is also cut off due to the rise of the rivers. El Uvero, La Plata, Ocujal, and Palmamocha, in the Santiago municipality of Guamá, remain cut off after the passage of Hurricane Melissa. Boca de Dos Ríos emerged as one of the hardest-hit areas.

articles.title: 'Climate inaction causing millions of avoidable deaths'
articles.author: Afp
articles.summary: Lancet Countdown is an annual study tracking the health impacts of climate change. 546,000 people died each year between 2012 and 2021 because of exposure to heat. Toxic fumes from wildfires killed a record 154,000 last year. Fossil fuel-related air pollution caused more than 2.5 million deaths in 2022 alone. Governments spent US$950 billion on fossil fuel subsidies in 2023.

articles.title: The era of Climate Change Alarmism is over
articles.author: Duane Rolheiser
articles.summary: There is a doomsday view that climate change is a threat to humanity. People will be able to live and thrive in most places on Earth for the foreseeable future. With the right policies and investments, innovation will allow us to drive emissions down much further. The Gates Foundation's top priority is health and development in poor countries. The pool of money available to help the poorest is shrinking as rich countries cut their aid budgets.

articles.title: Little penguin numbers increase on Granite Island despite algal bloom
articles.author: system
articles.summary: There is a significant increase in penguin numbers on South Australia's Granite Island due to the harmful algal bloom. The colony is fragile and lives on a very small number of surviving little penguins.       .   in South Australia.

articles.title: Can the People of South Asia Choose a Future of Unity and Cooperation?
articles.author: Bharat Dogra
articles.summary: South Asia has 25% of the world's population but only 4% of its land area. The region was ruled by colonial rule for two centuries before it achieved independence 78 years ago. It is highly vulnerable to climate change, related disasters and extreme weather situations, posing new and sometimes unprecedented risks for living, working and survival conditions. People of present landlocked countries like Afghanistan, Bhutan and Sri Lanka will have access to a vast coastal area in times of sea level rise. People from island countries like Bhutan will have wider protective options. The entire region should be united as the United Countries of South Asia (UCSA) with one union government.

articles.title: Antarctica's Ice Shelves May Collapse by 2300, Scientists Warn
articles.author: Srishti MS
articles.summary: Scientists warn that up to 59% of Antarctica's ice shelves could collapse by 2300, raising global sea levels by 32 feet and submerging coastal cities like London, Miami, and Shanghai. The most rapid collapses could start between 2085 and 2170. The outcome depends heavily on today's emission choices.

articles.title: Global Mysteries & Unexplained Phenomena
articles.summary: The economic fallout from increasing Atlantic hurricane seasons is projected to exceed $100 billion annually by 2050. Hurricane Melissa's devastation in the Caribbean is a reminder of the Caribbean's vulnerability to extreme weather events. Argentina's midterm elections delivered a blow to the ruling Peronist coalition, signaling a growing dissatisfaction with the country's economic woes. Donald Trump's recent travels through Asia demonstrate his continued influence on the global stage.

articles.title: At Podampeta, villagers highlight perils of climate change
articles.author: Hrusikesh Mohanty
articles.summary: Ahead of COP30 climate summit in Belem, Brazil from Nov 10-21, environment activists and villagers at Podampeta unveiled a giant climate bill, urging global leaders to make climate polluters pay. The bill presents a selection of extreme weather events in South Asian countries since the Paris Agreement was adopted in 2015.

articles.title: The Doomsayers' Bad Record
articles.summary: In the 1950s, there was a nuclear holocaust, in the 1960s a population bomb and deforestation. In the 1970s, we were warned about a new ice age and in the 1980s of a nuclear winter. The 1990s were overtaken by fear of Y2K and the 2000s produced the now-debunked hockey stick theory.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Steven Koonin writes in the WSJ, The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine recently issued a report on the effect of GHG emissions.' By DOUG SHERIDAN
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine recently issued a report on the effect of GHG emissions on the nation's climate, health and welfare. Steven Koonin writes in the WSJ that the report was obviously meant to bolster the scientific basis for the EPA's 2009 finding. The agenda is evident from the first sentence, which invokes the terrible flood of the Guadalupe River in Texas in July.

articles.title: Tragedy Strikes Western Kenya: Landslide Claims 26 Lives
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A landslide in western Kenya's Rift Valley has claimed 26 lives. 25 people remain missing, while 26 have been rescued and are receiving medical care. Military planes and disaster response teams have been dispatched to intensify search and rescue efforts. Climate change is causing more frequent and severe disasters in Kenya and Uganda.

articles.title: Houses in Río Cauto were left with water up to the ceiling after the floods
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa caused the Cauto River in Granma, eastern Cuba, to overflow, destroying homes and crops in its path. The authorities have deployed helicopters, amphibious vehicles, and Army rescue teams, but operations are progressing slowly due to the high water levels.

articles.title: Temps Are Dropping: How Often Should You Change Hummingbird Feeder Nectar This Winter?
articles.author: Sophie Pell
articles.summary: In summer, hummingbird feeders should be changed every 1-2 days to prevent mold and bacterial growth. In winter, it's important to change out the nectar in your feeder at least once per week when temperatures are below 60 degrees Fahrenheit. If you live in an area that gets freezing temperatures, you will need to keep an eye on the nectars to make sure they don't freeze.

articles.title: Jamaica farmers, fishing industry suffer after Hurricane Melissa smashes through Caribbean
articles.author: bamaap
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is blamed for at least 28 deaths in Jamaica. The storm destroyed the homes and infrastructure of Jamaican fishers and farmers who feed their families and nearby communities. The World Food Program is concerned about the impact on Cuba and Haiti's small-scale farmers.

articles.title: Mangroves Vital to Mitigating Cyclone Impact: Expert
articles.author: Dc Correspondent
articles.summary: Mangroves act as natural barriers, absorbing the force of winds and waves, thereby minimising coastal damage during cyclones. Godavari mangroves, spread over an area of 316 sq. km, effectively subdued wave impact during the 1996 cyclone in Coringa. The mangrove stretch currently extends from Hope Island to the southern end of East Godavara district.

articles.title: Jamaica Floods: Melissa Death Toll Climbs to 28
articles.summary: Jamaica's Hurricane Melissa has killed 28 people and devastated the western regions of the country. The economic repercussions of the storm will be felt for years to come. The Caribbean Development Bank estimated that the region faces annual economic losses of up to 5% of GDP due to climate change impacts.

articles.title: How Big Is Australia? Visualizing How Many Countries Fit Inside
articles.author: Pallavi Rao
articles.summary: Australia is the 6th-largest country in the world at nearly 3.0 million mi² (7.7 million km²). It's large enough to fit nine other countries, including 7th-ranked India. Around 40% of Australia is uninhabitable due to harsh desert conditions. Most of Australia's 27 million residents live along the coast.

articles.title: Climate change mitigation pathway: The 24-hour economy
articles.author: Oman Observer
articles.summary: As the sun soars and global cities set record temperatures, climate change is rewriting daily schedules and routines. The 24-hour economy is no longer a buzzword, it is an evolving industry. It's no longer about the past, it's about the present.

articles.title: Climate Change: WHO Identifies Five Key Interventions To Save Lives
articles.author: Chika Mefor-Nwachukwu
articles.summary: WHO has identified five key interventions that could save nearly 2 million lives every year. Interventions include establishing heat health alerts, transitioning healthcare facilities to clean and green energy, protecting water and sanitation systems, promoting clean energy for household use, and phasing out fossil fuels. WHO's appeal coincides with the upcoming COP30.

articles.title: Red Cross launches call to raise 18 million dollars for victims of Hurricane Melissa in Cuba
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) launched an emergency appeal to raise 15 million Swiss francs to help 100,000 people affected by the hurricane Melissa and an arbovirus outbreak in Cuba. The operation will focus on immediate life-saving assistance, early recovery, and strengthening long-term resilience.

articles.title: Cuban regime reveals number of housing damages following the impact of Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa left 1,318 total housing collapses in Cuba. 16,464 affected homes, 5,279 completely lost, 8,666 partially destroyed and 1,142 partial damaged. The Ministry of Construction has announced the sale of construction materials for those affected and the activation of tile production and the shipment of 1,000 tons of cement. The regime has not presented an official assessment of the damages.

articles.title: Report:Heat impacts on health in Scotland: Deaths 2005-2024
articles.author: biologyphenom
articles.summary: There was a slight increase in the maximum daily temperatures observed in Scotland in summer from 2005 to 2024. The average daily maximum temperature has remained relatively stable at approximately 17°C. 2024 was a relatively cool year compared to the previous 10 years. 2006 and 2018 both had six heat episodes in the summer months, whereas 2007 and 2010 had no heat episodes. In 2024, excess deaths were lowest (-54 excess deaths).

articles.title: Half of the Indigenous Peoples of the World Are at Risk of Disappearing. Richard Gere: 'How Long Do We See Them as Collateral Damage?'
articles.summary: Nearly half of the indigenous people living isolated from the rest of the world are at risk of disappearing in the next ten years, according to Survival International organization. The report was presented in London in the presence of the actor Richard Gere, who is also a member of Survival International.

articles.title: Jamaican farms reel from Hurricane Melissa, fueling fears of food shortages
articles.author: Korea Times
articles.summary: Osbourne Brumley's egg farm in Jamaica's St. Elizabeth parish couldn't withstand Hurricane Melissa's 150-mph winds. Brumly built the farm with his life savings.    "Melissa" is a Category 5 hurricane with winds of up to 150 mph.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa deals another heavy blow to Jamaica's farmers and fishers
articles.author: Lancaster Online
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has devastated Jamaica. It has caused severe damage to fishing and farming in the island nation.   It has also devastated Jamaica's fishing industry and farming industry. It is estimated that it will take years to repair the damage. It's estimated to cost billions of dollars.

articles.title: 10 coldest countries in the world; average temperatures drop to -4 degrees Celsius, Russia is 2nd, THIS country is coldest, name is...
articles.summary: The world's 10 coldest countries are Russia, Canada, Mongolia, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Kyrgyzstan, Estonia, Sweden and Tajikistan. The average temperature ranges from 7 degrees Celsius to -4.0 degrees Celsius in some parts of the countries.

articles.title: A huge Grok beatdown of climate hysteria
articles.author: Joe Bastardi
articles.summary: Grok explains the main reasons why some people claim climate change is an existential crisis, despite the data showing declining climate-related harms and successful adaptation. The main motives are: Financial Incentives (The Climate-Industrial Complex), Renewable energy firms, Subsidies, tax credits, green bonds, and green bonds. NGOs, Think tanks, Academia, Grants Research for 'impacts' $10B+/yr (NSF, EU Horizon) and political power.

articles.title: The blob is back in the Northern Pacific Ocean: What does that mean for B.C.?
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: A large-scale marine heat wave, known as a blob, is back in the northern Pacific Ocean, causing record warm ocean temperatures and a wetter-than-normal winter for the Pacific Northwest. Climate change is making these types of marine heat waves worse and more frequent, according to Chris Harley from UBC.

articles.title: Geraldine Osborne: Somewhere Cold: A Year Living in the High Arctic
articles.author: Square1
articles.summary: Geraldine Osborne spent a year living in the High Arctic with her three children under the age of 5. Anton and Geraldine discuss her new book, "Somewhere Cold: A Year Living In The High Arctic".    i.t.

articles.title: We can have growth while fighting climate change
articles.author: Sean Illing
articles.summary: Hannah Ritchie is a data scientist at the University of Oxford and author of Clearing the Air. She believes that the world is decarbonizing faster than most of us realize. The real bottleneck is not technology, but belief that progress is still possible without shrinking the world.

articles.title: 5 African countries added to U.S. high-risk travel list amid security concerns
articles.author: efosataiwo@vanguardngr.com
articles.summary: Mali, Niger, and Sudan have been classified under Level 4: Do Not Travel. Madagascar and Tanzania have been moved to Level 3: Reconsider Travel due to worsening safety concerns. The updated alert warns Americans to avoid or reconsider travel to regions affected by armed conflict, terrorism, violent crime, and deepening governance failures.

articles.title: The Nationals' decision on net zero will push Sussan Ley's leadership to the brink
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: It's all but inevitable that the Liberal Party will dump support for Australia to reach net zero emissions by 2050, as it's now all but certain that the party will dump its support for net zero CO2 emissions by the end of the century, too.

articles.title: Mark Gongloff: Bill Gates is wrong to quiet-quit the climate fight
articles.author: Mark Gongloff
articles.summary: Bill Gates seems to be quiet-quitting the fight against climate change. The Microsoft Corp. founder has long led the charge to keep the planet from overheating, dedicating money and attention to the cause. In a note on his website, Gates suggests negotiators at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil should help poor countries bolster their health and agricultural systems to withstand a hotter planet.

articles.title: Bill Gates is wrong to quiet-quit the climate fight
articles.author: Mark Gongloff
articles.summary: Bill Gates is giving ammunition to those fighting against further progress on climate change. In a note on his website, he suggests negotiators at next month's COP30 climate summit in Brazil should help poor countries bolster their health and agricultural systems to withstand a planet that's getting hotter. He conceded the temperature goals of the 2015 Paris accords were doomed under current conditions, but dismissed that as anything to worry about.

articles.title: Mark Gongloff: Bill Gates is wrong to quiet-quit the climate fight
articles.author: Mark Gongloff
articles.summary: Bill Gates seems to be quiet-quitting the fight against climate change. The Microsoft Corp. founder has long led the charge to keep the planet from overheating, dedicating money and attention to the cause. He's giving ammunition to those fighting against further progress.

articles.title: Jamaica confirms 28 deaths after Hurricane Melissa as relief operations are hampered
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: The death toll from Hurricane Melissa has risen to 28 in Jamaica. The storm has left communities cut off and emergency teams struggling to reach some of the worst-hit locations. The Red Cross reports that roughly 72% of the population remained without power in the days following the hurricane and about 6,000 people were sheltering in emergency centres. At least 31 deaths have been reported in Haiti and at least two in the Dominican Republic. More than 60,000 homes were damaged or destroyed in Cuba.

articles.title: Storm Melissa Sparks Crisis: Egg Shortage Looms Over Jamaican Farms
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed Osbourne Brumley's egg farm in Jamaica's St. Elizabeth parish, killing 28 people and damaging crops. Farmers predict food shortages and price hikes. The government is planning to stabilize supplies and support affected farmers, but recovery could be long-term.

articles.title: 'The population cannot be neglected': COE extends alerts due to active tropical wave
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: The director of the COE, Juan Manuel Méndez, warned that 'the population cannot be careless' due to the atmospheric conditions forecast for the next few hours. The province of San José de Ocoa remains on red alert. Monte Plata, La Altagracia, the National District, San Cristóbal, Peravia, La Romana, San Pedro de Macorís, and Santo Domingo are on yellow alert. Monseñor Nouel, Independencia, Puerto Plata and Santiago Rodríguez are on green alert.

articles.title: Bill Gates Has a Point
articles.author: Stephen Lezak
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa hit Jamaica on Tuesday, killing at least 50 people. Bill Gates wrote that climate change is a serious problem, but it will not be the end of civilization. Climate change is not a giant meteor crashing into Earth, but a series of injustices that create climate vulnerability in the first place.

articles.title: Efforts bringing aid to storm-stricken Jamaica
articles.summary: Rescuers and aid workers fanned out across Jamaica on Saturday to distribute food and water and reach communities still isolated four days after Hurricane Melissa. Hurricane Melissa left devastation in its wake, snapping power lines, toppling buildings, disrupting food distribution and destroying crop fields.

articles.title: Landslide leaves at least 21 dead in western Kenya
articles.author: Rédaction Africanews
articles.summary: At least 20 people have died and more than 30 are missing after a landslide in Kenya's western Rift Valley region. The most affected areas are still not accessible by road due to mudslides and flash flooding. More than 1,000 homes have been destroyed by the landslide in the hilly area of Chesongoch.

articles.title: On Politics: Hyperactive Gov. Green moves on SNAP cuts, climate woes
articles.author: Richard Borreca
articles.summary: Josh Green, Hawaii's governor, has been featured in Time Magazine's list of '100 people who represent the power of individuals to make significant progress in influencing the climate economy'. Hawaii is the first state to introduce a visitor green fee, which will generate $100 million annually to fund environmental restoration efforts and adaptation support. The state is also dealing with a financial crisis because of the shutdown of the federal government.

articles.title: Column: It's no debate that humans cause climate woes
articles.author: Charles “Chip” Fletcher
articles.summary: There is an overwhelming scientific consensus that human activity is the driver of recent global warming. Hawaii is vulnerable to climate impacts such as sea-level rise, deepening drought, heightened storm intensity and reduced rainfall. It is time to move beyond manufactured doubt and embrace the rigorous, consensus-backed science.

articles.title: A change in the weather — God speaks to a nation
articles.author: Bishop Dr Ryan Reddie
articles.summary: There is a change in the atmosphere and in the spirit of Jamaica. The heart of the national storm begins with how we treat one another. Kindness has been replaced by contempt. The spiritual climate in which our children grow determines the future of our nation. God does not send storms to destroy His people, but to draw them back to Him.

articles.title: Snowbirds (the feathered kind) are already flocking to Florida
articles.author: Jim Waymer
articles.summary: Millions of birds are arriving in Brevard County. BirdCast uses radar to generate real-time maps and forecasts of bird migration. Palm warbler, palm warbler the Eastern phoebe, Northern house wren, Cape May warbler and yellow-rumped warbler are some of the birds expected to land here.

articles.title: Study looks at productive vs environmental support focus of CAP
articles.author: Stella Meehan
articles.summary: The Joint Research Centre (JRC) has conducted an analysis of the potential impacts of two hypothetical scenarios related to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). The aim of the study is to contribute to policy discussions on the future of the CAP. The Scenar 2040 scenario shows production expansion lowering per-unit costs and domestic prices, strengthening EU competitiveness in global markets, but intensifying some environmental pressures.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa devastates Jamaica, wrecks homes, farms and fishing boats across coast
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is blamed for at least 19 deaths in Jamaica. The storm destroyed homes and public infrastructure. The damage will affect the livelihoods of Jamaican fishers and farmers. The World Food Program is concerned about the impact of the storm on Cuba and Haiti's small producers.

articles.title: Philippines braces for Typhoon Tino, suspends school, work and sea travel
articles.author: Atkia Marzan Shakira
articles.summary: Tropical Cyclone Tino is moving toward the Philippines. Provincial governments in Capiz province suspended all classes and government work beginning Monday. The Philippine Coast Guard halted all sea travel in Surigao del Norte province due to deteriorating sea conditions. Maritime authorities advised fishermen and small boat operators to seek safe harbor until the weather system passes. The weather agency projects the system will enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility on Sunday and intensify into a full typhoon by Tuesday.

articles.title: Grace under low pressure
articles.summary: Geese flew over Lewiston last week, seemingly unbothered by tumultuous clouds. August Frank/Lewiston Tribune August Frank reports. He reports that the geese did not seem disturbed by the weather.    August Frank, August Frank and August Frank report.

articles.title: Devastating Impact of Hurricane Melissa Worsens Crisis for Jamaican Farmers and Fishers
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa devastated Jamaica, Cuba and Haiti. It caused extensive damage to fishing boats and farms and killed at least 31 people. The World Food Program and other agencies are working to assess the full extent of the damage and provide assistance to affected communities. The increasing intensity of Atlantic hurricanes is linked to climate change.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa Devastates Jamaica's Fishing and Farming Communities
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has left a trail of devastation in Jamaica's fishing and farming communities. The storm's impact extends beyond Jamaica, affecting Cuba and Haiti's already vulnerable agricultural sectors. The road to recovery will require time, money, and extensive resources to rebuild shattered lives and restore economic stability.

articles.title: CLIMATE CHANGE AND THE FARMER'S CRY
articles.summary: The Sahel region of West Africa, stretching from Senegal to Chad, is one of the fastest-warming regions on the planet, with average temperatures rising about 1.5 times faster than the global average. Climate change has brought frequent droughts, flash floods, and desertification that threaten both crops and livestock. The decline in agricultural productivity has meant shrinking incomes and food insecurity for farmers in the Sahel. Women farmers, who make up nearly half of the agricultural workforce, are especially vulnerable to climate change adaptation strategies.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa: Jamaica & Caribbean Relief & Resources
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa killed 50 people and left 77% of Jamaica without power. The Northern Caribbean is on the front lines of a rapidly escalating climate crisis. The future of Caribbean resilience lies in leveraging technology and data-driven preparedness. The response to Hurricane Melissa underscores the importance of social resilience and solidarity.

articles.title: The Environmental Crises We Do Not See Coming
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: There was a hurricane in Jamaica, which caused a lot of damage and loss of life. This week's column is about the concept of 'creeping crises', which is slow, steady, subtle, quiet changes in our environment over a period of time. Guyana, the Caribbean, and the rest of the world need to be more aware of environmental impacts.

articles.title: Northward Expansion of Protected Vultures Poses Increasing Threat to Cattle Amid Climate Change Dynamics
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: There is a northward expansion of the range of black vultures in the United States due to climate change. There is an increase in vulture attacks on cattle in the Midwest and beyond. Vultures are protected under the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, which complicates management efforts.

articles.title: North Shore residents push for immediate erosion solutions
articles.summary: Oahu's North Shore is facing long-term beach loss due to winter swells. Hawaii Sea Grant and the North Shore Community and Trust held their first community meeting to discuss the new North Shore Beach Management Plan. Solutions proposed include dune restoration, sand management, and beach maintenance.

articles.title: Preparing Farmers for Climate Extremes
articles.author: Republica
articles.summary: Unseasonal rains caused by Cyclone Montha hit farmers in Koshi, Bagmati, and Terai provinces twice as hard. The cyclone's impact has been particularly severe in the Terai and Koshi plains. The Terai's agricultural system is under direct threat due to drought and untimely rainfall. Climate change is intensifying every year.

articles.title: Data reveals Victorians fleeing north as fallout from crime crisis continue
articles.summary: Victorians are beginning to opt for sun and sea changes for multiple reasons, including continuing crime issues and continuing weather changes.    -     Â   y   Y   a   i   e   in

articles.title: Data reveals Victorians fleeing north as fallout from crime crisis continue
articles.summary: Victorians are beginning to opt for sun and sea changes for multiple reasons, including continuing crime issues and continuing weather changes.       in the future, Victorians will opt for the sun and the sea changes, because of crime issues, weather changes and other reasons.

articles.title: Data reveals Victorians fleeing north as fallout from crime crisis continue
articles.summary: Victorians are beginning to opt for sun and sea changes for multiple reasons, including continuing crime issues and continuing weather changes.    -     Â   y   Y   a   i   e   in

articles.title: Researchers stunned as melting ice reveals ancient Viking treasures: 'It was like the glacier was giving us a gift'
articles.author: Alyssa Ochs
articles.summary: Norway's glaciers are melting at an alarming rate. Under the melting ice, archaeologists are discovering medieval and Viking-era artifacts. The discoveries offer insights into the craftsmanship and livelihood of Vikings and other people who lived and traveled throughout Norway over time. Increased glacial ice melt leads to higher tides during intense weather events, increased spread of disease and disrupts food systems.

articles.title: More exotic birds are winging their way to Ireland
articles.author: Sean O Riordan
articles.summary: Temperatures in Ireland are rising due to global warming. Several new species have already established a foothold in the country. The first Mediterranean gull was spotted in Ireland, in Cork, in 1964. Great white egret and great spotted woodpecker have been spotted in Cobh and Macroom.

articles.title: The Guardian and Guterres Are Wrong: Science Shows No Climate ‘Tipping Points'
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: A recent article in The Guardian claims that the planet is in danger of passing climate tipping points. There is no scientific basis for any so-called tipping points, and claiming otherwise is just fearmongering for political gain. The 1.5°C warming limit was already passed in 2024 because of the El Niño conditions.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa: Aid Efforts Hampered by Isolation
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa devastated Jamaica four days ago. Aid workers are still battling to reach isolated communities. Island nations are on the front lines of climate change and their ability to adapt will determine their future. Investing in resilient infrastructure and early warning systems are key to preventing future disasters.

articles.title: Coral Reefs Enter Irreversible Decline as CO2 Hits Record
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: 22 of the planet's 34 'vital signs' hit record extremes in 2024, with 2025 on the same trajectory. Ocean heat and ice loss fueled the largest coral-bleaching event and a 370% surge in fire-related losses. Tree-cover loss reached 29.6 million hectares in 2024. Ripple warned that every year of delay locks in higher risks and costs. Mike Barrett urged speed and cooperation.

articles.title: Rahul Gandhi Calls for Immediate Action as Cyclone Montha Wreaks Havoc in Andhra Pradesh
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Cyclone Montha destroyed 1.38 lakh hectares of agricultural land in Andhra Pradesh, impacting 1.74 lakh farmers with losses estimated at Rs 829 crore. A preliminary report submitted by the Andhra government to the Center pegged the total losses at Rs 5,244 crore.

articles.title: A warming Earth could accidentally trigger a deep freeze
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Earth's climate balance is not just governed by the slow weathering of silicate rocks. Silicate rocks capture carbon and release it into the atmosphere. It's not just about the silicate rock's temperature. It also has to do with the formation of CO2.
